conclusion: Calculate the time for a charged particle to pass through point O downward again after entering the magnetic field.
The particle follows a circular path due to the magnetic force.
In a magnetic field, a charged particle experiences a force given by F = qvB (Lorentz force).
The magnetic force acts as the centripetal force, leading to circular motion: qvB = mv^2/r.
The radius of the circle r is given by r = mv/qB.
The particle enters the first magnetic field B1 and moves in a semicircle.
The particle then enters the second magnetic field B2 and moves in another semicircle.
Given B1 = 2B2, the radii in each field will be different.
The period T of a circular motion in a magnetic field is given by T = 2πr/v = 2πm/qB.
The particle completes a semicircle in each field.
Time in B1: t1 = 1/2 T1 = πm/qB1.
The time it takes for the particle to pass through point O downward again is 3πm/qB1.
